DOC.HEAD: Lelyveld Succeeds Gelb As Times Managing Editor
DOC.TEXT: Joseph Lelyveld has been named managing editor of The New York Times, replacing Arthur Gelb, who is retiring, the newspaper announced Saturday. Lelyveld was promoted from foreign editor to deputy managing editor in July in anticipation of succeeding Gelb. Gelb, 65, will retire Sunday and become executive vice president of The New York Times Company Foundation, according to the announcement by Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, chairman of the Times Company and publisher of the newspaper. As managing editor, Lelyveld, 52, will be the main deputy to the newspaper's executive editor, Max Frankel. Lelyveld started at the newspaper in 1962 as a copy boy and has reported from New York, Washington, the Congo, India, Hong Kong, Britain and South Africa. He won the Pulitzer Prize in 1986 for his book about South Africa, ``Move Your Shadow.'' A graduate of Harvard University and the Columbia Graduate School of Journalism, Lelyveld has been a national correspondent for The Times Magazine and deputy foreign editor from 1977 to 1980. He became foreign editor in December 1986. Gelb worked 45 years at the Times, including as a reporter, critic, news editor and metropolitan editor. As a theater critic, he was among the first to recognize talents such as Barbra Streisand, Colleen Dewhurst, Woody Allen, Lenny Bruce and Dick Gregory. In his new position, Gelb will work with the foundation's president, Fred M. Hechinger, and will succeed Hechinger when he retires in September. The foundation supports charitable, educational, cultural, journalistic and environmental programs. The Times also announced that Carolyn Lee, 44, was appointed an assistant managing editor. She will succeed Warren Hoge as administrator of the 1,000-member news staff, with responsibility for personnel and business affairs. Hoge, also an assistant managing editor, will supervise news and feature coverage.
